content.user_title: Build FlowGram React Components with Best Practices
content.value_statement: Creating React components for FlowGram requires following specific patterns and conventions. This skill guides Claude Code through the complete component development workflow with TypeScript, Semi UI, and Storybook testing.
actual_capabilities: Guide creation of React components in FlowGram form-materials package structure
Generate TypeScript component code with proper type definitions and exports
Create Storybook stories for component testing and documentation
Provide code templates following FlowGram naming and structure conventions
Suggest proper usage of Semi UI components and internal dependencies
Generate component prop interfaces with appropriate TypeScript types
limitations: Only applicable to FlowGram project structure and conventions
Does not run automated tests or type checking directly
Requires manual verification in Storybook development environment
Limited to component patterns used in form-materials package

output_examples.input: Create a new ColorPicker component for selecting colors in form schemas.
output_examples.output: I will create a ColorPicker component following FlowGram conventions. First, I will create the directory structure under packages/materials/form-materials/src/components/color-picker/ with the main component file using Semi UI ColorPicker, proper TypeScript interfaces, named exports, and then add it to the main index exports. Finally, I will create a Storybook story in apps/demo-materials/src/stories/components/ to demonstrate the component usage.

output_examples.input: Add a story for the existing DataTable component showing pagination and sorting.
output_examples.output: I will create a comprehensive Storybook story at apps/demo-materials/src/stories/components/data-table.stories.tsx. The story will include a demo component that maintains state for pagination and sorting, demonstrate the DataTable with sample data, and include proper Meta configuration with component description and tags for autodocs.

best_practices: Always use named exports instead of default exports to enable tree shaking and improve bundle optimization.
Import React explicitly in all component files to avoid UMD global reference errors in TypeScript.
Keep component props minimal and focused on core functionality rather than adding excessive configuration options.
anti_patterns: Do not create separate npm packages for individual components. Keep all components in the form-materials package.
Avoid using external json-schema types. Always import IJsonSchema from internal packages.
Do not write unit tests for components. Use Storybook for manual testing and verification instead.

faq.question: Why use named exports instead of default exports?
faq.answer: Named exports enable better tree shaking in bundlers, making it easier to eliminate unused code and reduce bundle size. This is a project-wide convention for all FlowGram components.

faq.question: Which UI component library should I use?
faq.answer: Always use Semi UI components from the @douyinfe/semi-ui package. This ensures visual consistency across the FlowGram application and provides a comprehensive set of pre-built components.

faq.question: How do I test my component after creating it?
faq.answer: Run rush build:watch in one terminal to compile the package, then start Storybook with yarn dev in apps/demo-materials. Access your component story at localhost:6006 to test interactively.

faq.question: What is the correct way to import JSON Schema types?
faq.answer: Use IJsonSchema type from @flowgram.ai/json-schema package. Do not use external json-schema or JSONSchema7 types from other packages as they are not compatible with the project structure.

faq.question: Where should I place helper functions for my component?
faq.answer: Create a utils subdirectory within your component folder and place helper functions there with proper TypeScript types and copyright headers. Export functions using named exports.

faq.question: How do I fix React UMD global reference errors?
faq.answer: Add an explicit import React statement at the top of your file. This error occurs when React is used as a global in UMD builds but your file is an ES module.
